title: Ultra-fast 5G spectrum to go under the hammer in 2021
text:
"We specifically have an open allocation process, so if there are others who are interested, they will have the opportunity to bid,'' he said.

In the previous auction of the 3.6Ghz band in December last year, the government raised close to $1 billion. But Mr Fletcher said he had no expectations of how much the next auction would raise.

"We always avoid making any predictions, first because we don't want to influence the process, but second, the Act is clear that the purpose is to allocate spectrum to its highest value use, not to maximise revenue for the Commonwealth."

Mr Fletcher said the spectrum band was "pretty lightly used", meaning repurposing it would not be complicated. The most significant user was the Western Australian Police Force, which has a body scanning operation in that spectrum.

He said the 18-month delay actually represented a "pretty tight timeframe". The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission needs time to assess how much spectrum each telco should be allowed to purchase. The ACCC's objective is to ensure competition is not compromised by allowing one player to get hold of too much spectrum.

Before the auction, Mr Fletcher said the government hoped to pass legislation that would extend the licensing period to 20 years. Licences currently last 15 years. He said this longer timeframe would give telcos more certainty.

The auction would be conducted with the aim of allowing "rapid deployment of 5G technologies, the promotion of competitive market outcomes, and encouraging investment in infrastructure across both metropolitan and regional Australia".

Advertisement

“Making this spectrum available means that the Australian telecommunications industry can do what it does best - provide world-class telecommunications services for consumers, small businesses and enterprises. 5G will deliver speeds significantly faster than 4G and at much lower latency," he said.

The so-called millimetre wave spectrum has a much shorter range than the lower frequency bands used by 4G, meaning mobile network operators must install antennas and equipment in many more sites to achieve the same coverage.

Unlike the large sole-purpose towers used in macro-cell 4G networks, 5G makes use of "small cell" technology which can fit on smaller sites such as utility poles and the outside of buildings.

While its range is lower and it cannot penetrate walls as easily, millimetre wave spectrum allows higher speeds and lower latency than the lower bands, and can support much more traffic.

That means, in addition to the Internet of Things and smart city technology it can support, it also opens new possibilities for 5G fixed wireless broadband, which could be used as a high-speed alternative to the NBN's fixed-line broadband.

The auction will come more than two years after the first 5G spectrum auction, which covered the 3.6GHz frequency.

In that auction Telstra emerged with the biggest chunk of spectrum, spending $387 million for 143 lots.

Mobile JV, a joint venture between Vodafone and TPG, secured 131 lots at a cost of $263 million, while Optus was the third-biggest bidder, spending $185 million on 47 lots.
description: The federal government has laid out plans to auction off a large chunk of the valuable millimetre band spectrum in a move to open the 5G floodgates.
